head.title: Turnpike Agency Faults Federal Plan for Link

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey

hedline.hl1: Turnpike Agency Faults Federal Plan for Link

abstract.p: New Jersey Turnpike Authority rejects proposal by Federal Environmental Protection Agency to change proposed path of Route 92, asserting that its own plan is better for both commuters and the environment (S)

block.p: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority yesterday rejected a proposal by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to change the proposed path of Route 92, asserting that its own plan is better for both commuters and the environment.

Construction of Route 92, a proposed 6.7-mile link between Route 1 and the turnpike at Jamesburg intended to relieve north-south traffic congestion, has been delayed for 60 years by complications ranging from demographic shifts to budget constraints.

The New Jersey Turnpike Authority yesterday rejected a proposal by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to change the proposed path of Route 92, asserting that its own plan is better for both commuters and the environment.

Construction of Route 92, a proposed 6.7-mile link between Route 1 and the turnpike at Jamesburg intended to relieve north-south traffic congestion, has been delayed for 60 years by complications ranging from demographic shifts to budget constraints.
In October, the Federal agency, which must decide whether to approve the $300 million project, said the current proposal would damage wetlands, and it recommended a route several miles to the south.

In response, the Turnpike Authority issued a report yesterday criticizing the Federal agency's plan for failing to sufficiently reduce traffic on Route 1, and for disturbing agricultural and park land and 79 current or proposed residences.
Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the environmental agency, said it would review the Turnpike Authority's report and decide on the project within the next few months.
